poem:
Obituary, with Cloak

He came from power lines and timber,
to Oxford's new stone
where music had no shepherd.

Burly, bearded, a cloak
and silver cane—ridiculous,
therefore true.

He sang Bunthorne once;
the world applauded
and he withdrew,
as if praise were a door
closing on the real tune.

Stradella's racy ghosts
kept him, briefly,
before the chalk.
